facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 2009 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 2009 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 15, 1966 of the Punjab High Court in Civil Revision 1077 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the.judgment and order dated July 15, 1966 of the Punjab High Court in Civil Revision 1077 of 1966.

facts.text: Appellant was the tenant of certain land at Lahori Gate, Patiala.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the tenant of certain land at Lahori Gate, Patiala.

facts.text: The land in question is rented land within the meaning of s. 2(f) of the Act as it was taken by the appellant for the purpose of a firewood stall.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that the land in question is rented land within the meaning of s. 2  f  of the Act inasmuch as the land was taken by the appellant for the purpose of a firewood stall.

facts.text: The original owner of the land became an evacuee.

anchor.surface_text: The original owner of the land became an evacuee, and eventually the respondent purchased the land from the Managing Officer

facts.text: The respondent purchased the land from the Managing Officer and a sale certificate was issued in his favour on May 31, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: and eventually the respondent purchased the land from the Managing Officer and a sale certificate was issued in his favour on May 31, 1963.

facts.text: The appellant became the respondent's tenant after the purchase.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thus became the respondents tenant.

facts.text: The respondent filed an application for the ejectment of the appellant on a number of grounds.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the respondent filed an application for the ejectment of the appellant on a number of grounds.

facts.text: One ground for ejectment was that the respondent needed the land for erection of a residential house.

anchor.surface_text: One of the grounds in support of the claim for ejectment was that the respondent needed the land for erection of a residential house.

facts.text: Appellant's case was that even if the respondent required the land for construction of a residential house, he could not be given an order of ejectment under s. 13(3)(a)(ii).

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellant on the other hand was that even if the respondent required the land for companystruction of a residential house he companyld number be given an order of ejectment under s. 13  3   a   ii .

facts.text: The Rent Controller held that the respondent needed the land for constructing a residential house, not for business.

anchor.surface_text: The Rent Controller held that it was clear that the respondent did number need the land for running any business and only needed it for companystructing a residential house for himself.

facts.text: Rent Controller dismissed the ejectment application.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore he dismissed the application.

facts.text: The respondent appealed to the Appellate Authority.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then went in appeal to the Appellate Autho- rity.

facts.text: The Appellate Authority allowed the appeal and directed the tenant to put the landlord in possession.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Authority allowed the appeal. ... and the Appellate Authority allowed the appeal and directed the tenant to put the landlord in possession.

facts.text: Appellate Authority followed the decision in Municipal Committee, Abohar v. Daulat Ram, I.L.R. 1959 Punjab 1131.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Authority followed the decision of the Punjab High Court in Municipal Committee, Abohar v. Daulat Ram.  1

facts.text: The appellant filed revision to the Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then went in revision to the High Court

facts.text: Punjab High Court upheld the Appellate Authority and dismissed the revision.

anchor.surface_text: which upheld the view taken by the Appellate Authority and dismissed the revision.

facts.text: The appellant obtained special leave from the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant obtained special leave, and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, No. III of 1949 was passed in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed in 1949, and the purpose of the legislation was to restrict the increase of rent of certain premises

facts.text: The respondent required the land for constructing a residential building for himself and no other purpose.

anchor.surface_text: As in this case the landlord has stated definitely that he required the land for companystructing a residential building for himself and for numberother purpose

facts.text: Supreme Court held that the respondent is not entitled to eject the appellant under s. 13(3)(a)(ii) because the requirement is not for business.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the view taken in the case of Municipal Committee Abohar 1  is incorrect, and as the respondent landlord required the land in this case number for business or trade principally but only for companystructing a house for himself he is number entitled to eject the appellant under s. 13  3   a   ii .
Appeal by special leave from the.judgment and order dated July 15, 1966 of the Punjab High Court in Civil Revision 1077 of 1966.
Thereupon the appellant obtained special leave, and that is how the matter has companye up before us.
It is number in dispute that the land in question is rented land within the meaning of s. 2  f  of the Act inasmuch as the land was taken by the appellant for the purpose of a firewood stall.

anchor.surface_text: Sub- section  1  thereof, inter alia, lays down that a tenant in possession of a building or rented land shall number be evicted therefrom except in accordance with the provisions of that section.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  3  provides for special cases of eviction and the relevant provision with which we are companycerned reads thus -  3   a  A landlord may apply to the Controller for an order directing the tenant to put the landlord in possession. in the case of rented land, if-  a  he requires it for his own use  b  he is number occupying in the urban area companycerned for the purpose of his business any other such rented land, and  c  he has number vacated such rented land without sufficient cause after the companymencement of this Act, in the urban area companycerned.

concepts.interpretation: Sub-clauses (a), (b), (c) to be read together; (a) 'for his own use' implies principally for business or trade.
